issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

fields.summary: [C++] FixedSizeBinaryBuilder behaves incorrectly since v5.0 with "Resize+Advance" operation

comments.body:
The behaviour is changed by this commit: https://github.com/apache/arrow/commit/e990d177b1f1 , more specifically, changed by the diff in "Resize()" in `cpp/src/arrow/buffer_builder.h`.

I'm not sure if user can expect "Resize + Advance" always works, though.
I would suggest using Reserve() instead of Resize() here. Does it work for you?
Also, if you're really filling the data in non-increasing order, you probably don't benefit a lot from the ArrayBuilder classes, do you? You could fill up your buffers by yourself...

Reserve() doesn't work for FixedSizeBinaryBuilder as well.

Compared with other builders, e.g., IntBuilders, `FixedSizeBinaryBuilder` has an extra "bytes_builder" (a ResizableBufferBuilder), and doesn't override the "Advance()" method.

I would like to confirm if we can reply on the "Resize/Reserve + Advance" behaviour? Is it by-design or just happen to work? If is it by-design and expected to work, then we need to fix the FixedSizeBinaryBuilder, IMO.

I think the honest answer is that Advance isn't exercised or tested a lot in the Arrow C++ codebase, so there may be a bug to fix there :-)

Theoretically, Reserve + Advance should definitely work IMHO.
I have submitted a pull request to fix the behaviour. Hope it could be included in the next release.
Looking at the API exposed by array builders, I'm not even sure how Advance() is supposed to be used. How do you fill the null bitmap, for example?

We have a `PodBuilder` which inherits from the `FixedSizeBinaryBuilder`. There's a protect method that will expose its internal pointer and we use the PodBuilder for further data processing. After filling the data, we call the "Advance" method to get a `FixedSizeBinaryBuilder`.
That would be one way of doing it, but it's certainly not supported.

I've proposed to deprecate ArrayBuilder::Advance on the mailing-list:

[https://lists.apache.org/thread.html/r304b1266632c641a1d940aeb18426f1c069335feddb5f562513cde34%40%3Cdev.arrow.apache.org%3E]

The bitmap buffer is never touched and is a nullptr, and that is valid for arrow arrays. In our compute engine we also assume there's no null values in arrays and tables.

Its ok to me to depreated. If we have no plan for guarantee the semanticis, deprecation is better than undocumented/unspecified behaviour, IMO.
Transitioning issue from Resolved to Closed to based on resolution field value.
